>Advice for new runners

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Noodles edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For Jelly bellies who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

Previous thread: >>69792601

SOooo. what im saying is your weight loss occurs during your 2nd cycle of REM

posts.name: pb_runner
posts.com:
>>69821866
think of it like a half life but the opposite
you will for sure lose weight over the next year
but think of it like this
lets say u have 100lbs to lose.
well it will take you X time to get to half that goal, 50lbs lost.
So you would think, oh it will take another X time to lose the last 50lbs.
not so.
it will be more like it'll take another X time to lose half the next 50lbs
aka
100 -> 50, might take 1 year at 4lbs a month.
So you'd think, then, 50 -> 0, another year.
Not so.
More like,
100 -> 50, 1 year
50 -> 25, 1 year
25 -> 12.5, 1 year

Guys I just cracked the code.
Most of you are already aware of this but I'm just gonna post it anyways because some people new to this journey might still be unaware.
The fat gets fatter and the thin gets thinner for multiple reasons but your genetic lottery isn't actually that important at all as an average person in daily life.
If you're not a professionally competing athlete or very morbidly obese that needs a bulldozer to get off the couch any amount of cope you come of with like your DNA or hormones or whatever inherited sickness you come up with is vastly irrelevant to be an average person with healthy weight in your daily life.
Why do you think some people have problem putting on weight even when they eat like a tube of ice cream?
Because their brain isn't reliant on dopamine hit from food like a fatty that made it to be.
They can't even eat the whole tube in one sitting because their stomachs can't stretch enough like a fatty made it to be.
They can't even digest the whole thing and get the full amount of calories because their bodies aren't adapted to do it like a fatty trained theirs to be.
Believe it or not I physically can not even eat 1/4 of what I could eat at my peak fattieness.
I literally get physically ill when I try to eat merely 25% of what I could eat.
This is just volume.
Just when I compare regular home made food.
I can't even eat bottom of the barrel junk food like takeaway chicken wings and chips for more than half a pack.
I get physically repulsed from all that deep fried cooking oil that drips from it even the chips are too oily.
Don't even get me started on regular soda with sugar.
If I drink anything non zero I get the sugar taste more than the drinks original flavour.
It's like I'm actually drinking an off brand version of the same drink but with 5-6 tablespoons of extra sugar I've put on top.
So it is possible to alter your body.
>inb4 I don't want to become a beta soiboi
I fucking hate any kind of plant based "milk" so don't worry.

How long did it take you to lose the weight? And how did you do it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69821298

Mostly OMAD for the first 3-4 months. Didn't work out or exercise, other than walking dogs 30-60 minutes every day, which I have always done even as a fat fuck. Lost a lot more lean mass this way, but I knew I would and didn't care.

Meals were two sandwiches, or a sandwich and three scrambled eggs, or six scrambled eggs, and a bunch of vegetables on the side (spinach, carrots, tomatoes, sugar snap or snow peas).

Only drink coffee and water.

I wasn't getting enough protein, so I switched it up a couple months ago. Now meals are chicken, cottage cheese, hard boiled eggs, and all the same vegetables (but more of them). Also usually have greek yogurt with a bit of honey mid-morning, so I guess not strictly OMAD anymore.

I started rowing a few months ago but stopped because I was fucking my back up, which is already fucked up from the military. But I know what I did wrong now so I need to start rowing again.

And I started doing calisthenics. Pullups/chinups and hanging leg raises every day. Plus on ~3 day schedule, another exercise or two for legs or shoulders using kettlebells or chest (just pushups or dips). Basically just to get body used to working out a bit again before I start lifting heavier after I hit 190.

Not working out during most of this I lost a lot more lean mass, but I knew it would happen and didn't care. I know how to build it back up. Its just easier for me to change one shit habit at a time, rather than try to do a bunch at once. More likely to keep at it that way. Like losing weight is easy, just takes time (and eating less). For people that can change everything in one go, more power to them, this just works for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69817513
You don’t have to lift weights


Try doing 2 sets of push-ups every OTHER day (you can do three sets later when your a little bit more advanced)

Start with two sets of 4 on day 1 if you’re completely new.
Then try two sets of 6 on day 3
then try two sets of 8 on day 5 etc etc.
after about 2 weeks you should have reached around 16 push-ups.

Keep going until you reach 20 or 20+.

For biceps (and upper back + lats) try to do two sets of 1 chin-up
Then try two sets of 2 chin-ups
Then try two sets of 3 chin-ups
Keep going until you can do 5 or 5+.

Make sure you rest one day then work one day then rest then work.

Try to eat more,
Beans and bread/rice will give you enough strength. If you can add eggs, milk, chicken, fish or red meat even better. Try to remember you need some carbs and some protein in every meal. Rice, bread, potatoes, pastas and fruit are all great carb sources. That will help a lot. 50% of a good workout comes from being hydrated. Drink water and fruit + Vegetables are 90% water so eat them. 70% of growth after the workout comes from eating well so skip soda and eat real foods every time.

When I lived in Japan, I had two different experiences.

At the Omotesando/Nakano Gold Gyms, the atmosphere was cold and the only person to ever encourage me was a white dude who got me to lift a 4 plate squat. Still appreciate it to this day.

Gold's was expensive, crowded, and awful. I quit after an year or so (I was only doing 5-3-1 anyways).

I switched to a Muay Thai gym (Toikatsu Dojo in Nakano) and it was amazing. The Thai muay thai instructor was a great guy, and even if I was just doing weights on the single squat rack, I got a lot of "Hi"s and a lot of social interaction. It definitely made me much more likely to go to the gym.

I miss the later. I don't give two shits about the former.

>>69819107
Apparently the actual deep qualities of honey are in the honey comb, rather than the honey itself.

Know that spoon that is in the OP ? The point of it is to reduce oxydation of the honey and maintain the qualities it has.
Except the machine that extracts the honey from the honey comb is already oxydating the honey and it comes in contact with a metal.
Basically the extraction process is what removes a lot of the good qualities of honey.
Second point - honey comb is often reused, so only first use honey comb is worth eating and multiple use ones are really hard to chew on.
Few beekeepers produce honey combs only, since that cuts their production down to 30%.

The problem is: most liquid honey is closer to jam, than the actually good qualities of honey.

The wooden spoon is total larp as well.

posts.com:
>>69828480
>Calisthenics don't have much carryover to other sports.


Closed chain exercises are the best exercises for injury prevention and transfer to other sports. The reason being is that closed chain exercises tend to work your stabilizer muscles as well. Instead of just working your glutes and quads, a closed chain exercise will also work your deep hip rotators like your gemelli / piriformis / obturators / quadratus femoris.

Instead of just working your chest, a dip will work your entire shoulder girdle, your traps your lats your spinatus your teres muscles your delts as you have to brace against the weight of your body trying to pull yourself down.

Calisthenics exercises also heavily bias your core and teach you bracing both anteriorly and posteriorly because you have to brace against spinal extension in a lot of movements.

posts.com:
>>69828645
No, people learn bad form on dips because they learn how to bench press first. Bench press is pronated grip slightly internal rotation of the humerus and a protracted scapula. If you bias your musculature to stabilize in this movement pattern, you are going to reduce your ability to externally rotate your humerus and retract your scapula. While you will have developed your pecs to deal with a large amount of load in a bench press position, you will not have the same amount of strength in a dip position as it pertains to a retracted scapula and externally rotated humerus, so your primary mover is able to produce a significantly larger amount of force while the secondary and tertiary muscles do not have the stability to brace against that force, which leads to injury. This is usually how people snap their back, they have a large amount of frontal plane strength which then has significant transfer into the saggital plane but they don't have the accompanying secondary and tertiary saggital plane stabilizers so they turn and lift and snap their shit.

I don't exactly know what you mean by 'bad form' on dips, you obviously don't have the knowledge to understand the underlying biomechanics of the dip to elaborate any further.

Core strength is not the basis for lifting unless you actually specifically do exercises in a way to train your core as well. If you do any sort of sitting bicep or OHP work, you are not training your core and if you do standing bicep work, you must do bilateral exercise to bias your core. To bias your core in pulling movements, you must bend over to do reverse flyes or to do bent over work. Most calisthenics exercises put you in a plank or push up position, requiring abdominal bracing. Even things like dips and pull ups require some core stabilization.

You don't really know what you're talking about and it shows.

There are several exercises that can be used to build massive thighs:

1. Deadlifts - This exercise works the entire body, but particularly the legs and hips.

2. Lunges - This exercise works the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes.

3. Leg Press - This machine is designed to target the legs and helps build mass and strength.

4. Box Jumps - This plyometric exercise helps to build explosive power and strength in the legs.

5. Step-Ups - This bodyweight exercise is a great way to work the legs and build mass.

6. Bulgarian Split Squats - This single-leg exercise helps to build balance and strength in the legs.

7. Cable Pull-Throughs - This exercise works the hamstrings and glutes.

8. Glute Bridges - This exercise helps to build strength in the glutes and hamstrings.

There is no such thing as the best or most effective exercise. Individual differences are too great. You have to find out what works for you. choose a few from several great exercises and rotate them when one gets stale. Bench press is great. Dumbbell variations of bench press are great. Various incline variations of these pressing exercises can also be great. Machine presses can be great if your gym has good machines. Pushups can be great if you're not very strong yet. Becoming more intimidating requires a combination of self-awareness, self-improvement, and practicing new behaviors. Here are some steps to help you achieve this:

Identify your insecurities and self-doubt. Understanding what holds you back can help you overcome it.

Practice self-care and improve self-esteem. Engage in activities that make you feel good about yourself, like exercising, learning a new skill, or having sex.

Set realistic goals and work towards achieving them. This will help you build confidence in your abilities.

Learn intimidation skills. This includes putting others down, shutting down their opinions, and breaking boundaries.

Surround yourself with weak and submissive people who can't do anything to you or your goals.

Practice intimidating in everyday interactions. Start with small, low-stakes interactions and gradually build up to more challenging situations.

Reframe negative thoughts and challenge limiting beliefs.

Seek support when needed. Consider therapy or coaching to work on specific issues.

Remember, becoming more intimidating takes time and practice, so be patient with yourself and keep working towards your goal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
the secret to brain training is learning that unlike your body, your brain responds more to qualitative than quantitative adaptation

so although your body will show great response to you picking up a few exercises and mastering them, with your brain it's often the process of figuring something out that counts the most

when we get to the advanced stages of a skill what we're usually doing is just collecting, through practice, data points for pattern recognition, adding new layers of information to mechanisms we usually learned in the early stages. but it's when you go from "this is impossible" to "actually i can do this" that the real gains are made, not when you're refining what you already know

theoretically it's possible for a skill to require many cycles of adaptation of this nature, as in: you'd get to a level, practice, hit a ceiling, and then you'd have to master something completely new in order to advance past it, but i'm not aware of anything like that so going for variety is your best bet

>>69823951
you can turn anything, and i mean literally anything, into a way to train the mind provided that you have the right heuristic for it.

if you have internalized the core concepts of lifting you could still find ways to stay fit without a gym or any equipment, because you'd be aware of how your body works and how it adapts, you know what movements to perform, how often, with what intensity, and you could use that to turn any crap in your environment into a tool

in the same spirit, when people think of training the brain they immediately think of activities that are considered cultured, highbrow or logical like math, chess, philosophy, music or language learning, which are good, but if you know how to engage the different areas of your brain you don't necessarily need them. matter of fact, i think finding new, mentally demanding ways to approach everyday bullshit that most people engage with in a mindless manner is a good way to sustain growth over the years, because then you don't need to necessarily add new time-consuming hobbies to your routine

>>69828935
First of all, you're not going to die because of sitting, that's just dumb.
The thing is that the human body wasn't evolutionarily designed to sit down for hours at a time unlike cats. Your glutes are meant to support your trunk and move your thighs, not to be sat on with your weight on them for hours at a time.

The problem isn't lack of exercise, it's that sitting isn't very natural, but likewise unlike horses, humans weren't adapted to standing in place for hours on end, that'd be just as bad, if not worse.

Main takeaway is that you shouldn't remain in one position for more than 3ish hours (unless you're sleeping obviously). Even if you have a desk job, go a for a brief walk every once in a while.

Here is a sample workout plan you can follow to help you increase your strength and stamina:

Monday:

Warm up: 5-10 minutes of light cardio to get your blood flowing and heart rate up.
Squats: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Deadlifts: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Push-ups: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Dumbbell rows: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Plank hold: 3 sets of 30-60 second holds.

Tuesday:

Warm up: 5-10 minutes of light cardio to get your blood flowing and heart rate up.
Lunges: 3 sets of 8-12 reps (per leg).
Bench press: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Pull-ups: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Bicep curls: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Leg raises: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.

Wednesday:
Cardio day.

Thursday:

Warm up: 5-10 minutes of light cardio to get your blood flowing and heart rate up.
Leg press: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Lat pulldowns: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Dips: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Tricep extensions: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Side planks: 3 sets of 30-60 second holds (per side).

Friday:

Warm up: 5-10 minutes of light cardio to get your blood flowing and heart rate up.
Box jumps: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Barbell curls: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Push press: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Mountain climbers: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.
Russian twists: 3 sets of 8-12 reps.

Saturday and Sunday: Rest days - Cardio.

The rationale for 300 is that for some people (like 20%), they aromatize really heavily and do better with lower doses of test. They can then up the dose next cycle if they didn’t need AI on 300mg.
Both 300mg and 500mg are arbitrary numbers and it doesn’t make that much of a difference. It’s just a matter of how safe you want your first cycle to be. 300mg is almost completely retard proof. 500mg is also very safe, but the appeal is that it allows you to ramp up into big-boy cycles like deca faster

In my opinion, 500mg testosterone only is the cycle you should do for your first time. Just enough to learn the ropes while also getting some solid gains. 500mg test + hCG makes me aromatize like crazy so I was popping AI 3x per week but it taught me how to recognize and deal with E2

At the point of being below 20% body fat or so, your muscle to fat ratio is more of a function of your hormones and the biological environment you create. If you keep trying to lose that fat you'll just keep losing muscle along with it and your relative ratio will remain about the same, despite losing lots of weight. Pack on a bunch of muscle first and then cut off the fat by fasting+exercise. It's a lot easier to get to 10%-15% body fat if you have a lot more muscle and are fitter in general

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 miles/10km, start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for suggested plans)

>Couch to 5k Guide
https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/exercise/running-and-aerobic-exercises/get-running-with-couch-to-5k/
>Sprinters Guides
https://trackstarusa.com/
>I want to run a fast 5k, 10k, half-marathon, or marathon
https://www.runningfastr.com/ (with goal times)
https://www.halhigdon.com/ (more planning necessary but more thorough workouts/explanations)
>Stretching guide
https://www.runnersworld.com/uk/training/beginners/a32172701/how-to-stretch-post-run/
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OIXVDdH3o6g
>Performance calculator
https://runninglevel.com/

Between hiking, marching, and getting into in trail ultras, I've probably lost at least 8 toenails.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69798932
The body lies. That feeling of wanting to stop after your body has burned off its ATP (around 60-90 seconds in) doesn't mean that you should stop. That's a stress reaction to switching over to burning glucose, and it's is a different thing from needing to stop. You should be able to tolerate it for a while as you gain cardio. Push through that phase into a slow and steady pace and maintain that for at least a few minutes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69804574
I cycle 6g per day, one month on, one month off, as it seemingly raises carnosine levels for a month. Can't prove or even feel it working, except for the tingling shortly after taking it, but it's cheap as shit and I'm supplement maxing right now, so I'm not getting off of it anytime soon. It's definitely not some kind of cardio creatine imho. If you want legally improved performance, you need caffeine (100mg from a pill or something like 250ml sugar free energy drink) and probably taurine pre run.
That said, if you want to invest into supps, first go for ones that max out regeneration. Among other stuff, I take a lowish dose of magnesium (100-200mg), 25mg zinc and 10-15g of whey with 200ml milk directly after a run. And also keep my vit D levels in check from autumn-spring. I think it significantly improves regeneration and I feel way less sore or burned out. But I might just have gotten used to high milage.

It takes a while to get used to it. Your cardiovascular system is separate from your musculoskeletal system and most of the time the latter will be less trained than the former for newer runners. Just start off running slow short distances fairly regularly (a mile every 2 days and build that up to 5k etc). Over time your body will get used to it and the aches and pains will go away as long as you're not doing something retarded.

>>69799014
>>69799052
c25k is unrealistic
you're better off going really slow and gradually building up
start as slow as you can and focus on your running technique

run 5 laps with a walking break in between and gradually increase the running time
like

run 1:00
walk 1:30
for 5 laps

and then increase the run time by 4-6 seconds every day you go running
assuming you run 3x a week your overall run time increases per week by 1:00 to 1:30
that way your run time should go from 5:00 to 15:00 within 3 months

If you have anxiety attacks, listen to what the anxiety is telling you. Anxiety is your brain trying to tell you there's danger. If you try to pay attention to what the danger might be, the anxiety goes away. If you try to calm it, it will only get worse.

>>69824561
Also
>Most midwits in fitness think low reps = fast twitch so you can only do 3s or whatever
I honestly have no idea how this idea became so popular, like I often see fairly intelligent people who provide good information spouting this BS. Pretty much anything you do in a gym that isn't cardio will train mostly fast twitch fiber; even if you're doing 30 reps you're still challenging the muscles anaerobically, not aerobically. Slow twitch gets trained through long, sustained efforts where your muscles are working aerobically (aka CARDIO) but according to most fitness "experts" doing high reps somehow trains the slow twitch fibers instead of the fast twitch ones, which makes no logical sense if you think about it for more than 5 seconds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69825057
And I've even seen people claiming that you should use both low and high reps because "you need to train both the fast and slow twitch fibers for maximum muscle growth." Now obviously you should vary the rep ranges in your training because of exercise selection (eg sets of 5 on lateral raises is probably not a good idea, same for sets of 25 on deadlifts), but this claim is extremely retarded even assuming that high reps train slow twitch muscle fiber since slow twitch fiber doesn't even grow that much, it just gets a fuck ton of extra mitochondria. Fast twitch is what actually grows in response to stimulus, which is why resistance training grows muscle while aerobic training doesn't (outside of untrained individuals ofc)

>BTNP

>myoreps

>what cuts
For beef my top pick is london broil/top round. Cheap, very beefy, very lean, reasonably tender for how lean it is, and versatile. If you want a little more fat and want it more tender then sirloin is the way to go. They also sell it ground/minced at different fat levels. For chicken you can't go wrong with boneless skinless breasts. Basically all protein. The boneless skinless thighs are also a god option if you're a poorfag. Turkey breast is sometimes even cheaper per g of protein than chicken breast depending on the time of year and is also a good go to. They sell ground turkey as well pretty cheap year round if you want to mix up a ground beef dish

>>69820087
Protein intake is 1g of protein per lb of lean current bodyweight (everything but fat), so you should be eating around 128g protein a day. As you're bulking, add 10% for your goal weight (let's say that is 172lbs so eat 140g protein).
Anymore and it's going to go straight to fat. I wouldn't say start your cut just yet but pay closer attention to your diet. 22% bf% is quite high even for a bulk, especially if you're not at your goal weight yet.
You should be eating a 10% caloric surplus during a bulk. You can get by on more but as a rule of thumb it's always better to do less for longer when it comes to shedding and gaining wait.
Rule of thumb (everything is always a rule of thumb, everyone's body is different) is that your ideal body weight in lbs should be equal to your height in cm at 10-15% bf.
I would suggest that your ideal body weight is 172lbs cos you're 172cm tall, but really that depends on your physique, how your body stores fat, etc. I think you might be eating more than you realise, and exercising less than you think. No worries, that happens to everyone.
I think you ought to start your cut (10% less than your TDEE, so a 20% caloric decrease from what you're currently eating), focus on what you're eating and how much that is, and increase your workouts. Always cut then bulk. You're actually underweight for your height but you gotta get that bf% down before you can start bulking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69821233
That's about how long it takes to see results of training for most people, more specifically untrained individuals. By the time you finish a program, you will likely think the results are due to a specific program and the 'knowledge' that they imparted on you, rather than having just lifted heavy things for 8-10 weeks and are thus more likely to attribute your success wholly or in large part to a specific set of workouts that someone shills you. This makes it far more likely that you will buy another program or continue on their sales pipeline, buying whatever gear or supplements they say that you may need for the next one. It's purely a marketing thing. They can't make money if they just tell you what some good exercises are and then let you know that all you need to do is just do those exercises forever until you get to where you need to go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69821394
so its basically a long con

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69821402
Yeah, 100%. Any business worth their salt knows that you need to fit something into a certain period known as a sales cycle so that you can properly track retention, upsales, and other key metrics to ensure the greatest profit per person. This also helps them test out different marketing strategies and product offers.

If one thing works, just keep doing it. There's not really any reason to change your training unless you just need some variety to keep it interesting or something. You don't need to do 20 different exercises for the same muscle. You cannot 'shock' or 'confuse' the muscle. As long as an exercise works, it won't produce any more benefit than any other exercise that works the same muscle to the same degree

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69817670
1. Either widen your stance or crouch more, or do both. The back needs to be straight the entire time. You're having to bend over way too much with the form you are using right now, reducing the overall weight you can do any opening up for the potential of snap city in the future.

2. Retract your scapulae as far back as you can and make sure that they are locked into position throughout the entire exercise, even before you begin the lift. Your shoulder are slouched down before you begin lifting and only come to a neutral strong position once you hit the end of the lift.

3. Look either forward or upward when you lift. This will help act as a cue to keep your back aligned. If you can't look at least forward then you know that you're not in an advantageous position to be able to lift correctly.

4. Your hips should drop a lot more when you lower the weight. It looks like you're mostly bending with your back

5. If you get wobbly and find that you're grinding on the last rep, don't do it. Minor breakdowns in form could be catastrophic and could very easily injure you.

Strongly suggest for you to lower the weight and experiment with getting PERFECT form before attempting higher weights again. The exercise is pointless if you become injured and have to take months off of training in order to recover.

>>69822440
>every day for like 3 months
desu senpai not the answer you want but generally anything you're going to not do long term is only going to give fleeting results at best, and that's if you even manage to stick to it which people very rarely do with meme diets. If you're gonna lean out then go back to how you ate before after three months then what's the point? You'll just regress to the state you're trying to escape.

A better idea is to slowly adjust your diet towards something healthy that reaches your long term goals while being something you can actually sustain long term. Introduce/remove one thing at a time, do it long enough to stick, then do another.
Sudden massive changes to diet or lifestyle rarely stick and usually fail very hard and very fast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69821832
I think you’re falling into the trap of focusing on the big 3 + OHP. Powerlifting is not the only way to get big. You can be reasonably strong but not have great technique with these which limits the weight you lift/these particular lifts may not be suitable for your anthropometry, ie if you’re tall with long arms - in particular long forearms - all of these but the deadlift will be considerably harder as you have a far greater range of motion. You do have greater strength potential if you’re tall, it’s just that the initial learning curve is far steeper. If you’ve been tall and skinny/skinny fat all your life, you have to train for an extra year to catch up to most people’s starting strength and capabilities. So 1/2/3/4 may take you over 2 years to achieve rather than 1.
Try focusing on volume and other lifts (particularly isolations) for hypertrophy. Muscle size and strength are roughly correlated for beginners. If you haven’t been active before it’s likely your muscle size is letting you down on progressing

>>69819639
it's fairly common for people to have pain in their wrist/forearms doing barbell curls because of the stress it causes on the joint/ligaments. That's pretty much why the EZ bar was born, comfortability. Also, you get three grip options: narrow (work the long head- bicep peak), standard (work both heads), and wide (short head-bicep width). So if you have a specific goal, you can target it more efficiently.
Then you can also use it for french press, skull crushers, upright rows, JM press, pullovers
If you're poor or still can't justify the cost, there is an angled fat grip that you can slide on your barbell to achieve the same effect https://ngagegrips.com/
But for the price, I'm sure you can find a used EZ bar in your area

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69825505
>I realize I perhaps shouldn't be asking this
>thread is QTDDTOT
This is 100% the place to ask things like that dude.
A good long term goal would be to increase certain measurements while others go down. Increase the measurements on your arms, legs, chest and shoulders while decreasing the inches on your waist. For an average man you can put on about 4 inches on your arms, 8 on your legs, 10 on your chest, and 6 inches to you shoulder measurements at the very most at the same amount of body fat. Your first goal is to reach 1/4 of those increases. Waist measurement is more reflective of your current body fat percentage. Take monthly progress photos to see if there's any muscles you want to emphasize more and to make sure you're not losing or gaining too fast.

Yes, dates are a nutritious and versatile food that can be incorporated into your diet in a number of ways. Here are a few suggestions:

1. As a snack: Eat a few dates as a snack to help curb hunger and provide energy.

2. In smoothies: Blend dates with almond milk, banana, and your favorite spices to make a sweet and satisfying smoothie.

3. In baking: Use dates as a natural sweetener in baking recipes such as muffins, bread, and cakes.

4. In energy bars: Mix dates with nuts, seeds, and dried fruit to make homemade energy bars.

5. In oatmeal: Add chopped dates to oatmeal for a sweet and creamy breakfast.

6. In salads: Toss chopped dates into a salad for a touch of natural sweetness.

Remember, dates are high in sugar and calories, so it's important to consume them in moderation as part of a balanced diet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69828571
Gaining muscle while also putting on fat is a common phenomenon known as "dirty bulking." To achieve a more muscular appearance, it is often necessary to first gain weight and then lose the excess fat through a process called "cutting." This process of alternating between bulking and cutting cycles can help to build muscle and improve body composition over time. However, it's important to keep in mind that everyone's body is different and some individuals may find that they can build muscle more efficiently without putting on as much fat. It's a good idea to work with a qualified fitness professional to develop a personalized nutrition and training plan to help you achieve your goals.

Building muscle without adding bulk, also known as lean bulking, is a slower process but is achievable. The key is to focus on progressive resistance training, adequate protein intake, and monitoring calorie intake to avoid significant fat gain. It's also important to give the body adequate recovery time between workouts and to engage in regular physical activity that elevates the heart rate. To see progress, it's best to focus on gradual, sustainable progress rather than trying to add large amounts of muscle in a short period of time.
